newsitem.title: USA: NJ group urges $200 mln more for open space -- paper.
newsitem.headline: NJ group urges $200 mln more for open space -- paper.

text.p: A New Jersey task force called on the state to spend $200 million more a year to preserve farmlands, woodlands and historic structures, the Star Ledger reported Thursday.

The Governor's Council on New Jersey Outdoors, in an interim report to be made public next week, said the new spending could allow the state to acquire an additional one million acres of ecologically important land and maintain land the state has already purchased.

Gov. Christine Whitman appointed the panel last year to find ways to finance open space preservation, but the council stopped short of making such recommendations. The newspaper said council members hope to answer the question after the November election.
New Jersey has traditionally relied on a series of "Green Acres" bond initiatives to finance open space acquisitions. The bond questions have won widespread support in recent elections.
New Jersey plans to use about $144 million of such bond funds in fiscal 1997 for land perservation.
